title: People Programme in FP7
segmentation: Thank you very much and I'm big on, you know I'm the acting head up units of Marie Curie actions unit dedicated to networks to the networks activity.
I'm going to be a speaking today about the one other part of this program, which is the people we just have been said earlier on today, is dedicated to mostly too.
The Marika reactions in in.
At.
I want first to put you all in the wider political context.
This is not something which is just standing alone.
There's a whole series of issues which I think have been probably mentioned throughout the this.

This morning's presentation and I would sort of maybe link back to this idea of the virtuous circle referring to education and training, attracting researchers which attract companies which attract investment.
So we are really at the core of these virtues.
A circle because one of our main emissions is really to create the conditions for researchers to have a career in Europe.
To be making Europe more attractive to the researchers.
And also you will see along this presentation that industry will also have a very important participation in our actions.
So there are three broad objectives within our Marie Curie actions.
One of them is to create the conditions for the researchers to be mobile without any obstacles.
This is something which.
Already happened during FP6 and will continue with this and with this I'm refering among other things to the scientific visa and to the code and conduct of code code and Charter for researchers.
This is something which started as I said FP6 and is something which is becoming more and more common amongst all the participating institutions in the European research.
Then of course another important part is to enhance the status and the attractiveness of a career in Europe.

We are aware that one of the main problems in Europe in terms of attracting researchers is the lack of a structure and a lack of recognition of the research offers researchers as a profession, and this is something again that we are sort of very worried about and very concerned about making everything possible to make a career structure more and more common.
In Europe.
This if we want people to become researchers, we have to make it attractive and this is a case for example in in in Slovenia, if we want to attract researchers to Slovenia.
And we have to improve also their career conditions.
And finally we have to put the money where our words are.
So basically we have to finance the researchers training, mobility and career development and this is what I'm going to be talking.
About now, So what are the main features of the people programming FP Seven?
Well, a Zoran has earlier on spoken about the continuity of FP7 in regard as regards to FP 6 and we're doing a lot of that.
What we're doing is not cutting what had worked in the past, but actually progressing with this idea that we have already learned from the past.
In fact, what we have been very pleased to see that the budget has been increased in practically 50.

Percent per year and the fact is that in the past all our actions Merrick reactions were part of specific programs and now actually it's been recognized by all the Member States and the research community that these actions are so important for the research community that they have been put forward as a specific program on their own right.
And then of course, I said earlier on we have to increase the private sector participation.
This is something which is overall.

Yeah, the framework care program and we are also being part of of of this the the public sector and the private sector have to work together to bring innovations to something that again has been set today repeatedly.
And to achieve this we have to also change the culture that exists between academia and the power and the private sector.
We know that this is really an obstacle for this to work and we've seen it with our researchers.
The fact that when there has been mobility interested.

Intersectorial mobility this has had a negative effect on their careers, so again, all our programs are going to be developing in the sense of creating a better synergy between the two sectors and a better communication between them.
We have to also strengthen international dimension.

This is I'm mentioning something which earlier on has already been mentioned in terms of their global FP 7 aims, so again, our actions will be open to third country participation and also we will have specific actions which will be directed to this international Corporation.
We will continue as we did in FP 6 by ensuring that there's a balance, gender participation, and another thing that we will continue with is the fact that we will have no semantic product.
Priorities will continue to be a bottom up program.
That means that we cover all the areas of scientific research.
So just to briefly take you through our actions, this is a summary of the actions that we have in total.
You can see that we have quite a lot of action, so I cannot go in full detail, but afterwards I'm open to all questions if you need or even afterwards outside when we finish the session.
But just to give you an idea we have, although they're quite a lot, we have compressed a lot from the past.
Also, in the past we had you, probably many of you who know about FP.
Six we had a whole series of excellence.
Actions many times we get the questions.
Where are those actions?
Well, part of them have now been integrated in our American reactions in the People program, and I'm glad to say that in some ways this is very, very popular.
Excellence grants that many people were interested in.
In some ways they have a continuity, and in a much larger and broader view with the European Research Council.
Because these in some ways they're taking on board.
This this idea of excellence for researchers who are in the first postdoctoral years to give them independence.
So I'm not going to go on with this because we have had a very detailed.
Mention about this.
I will go now onto the initial training networks.

This initial training networks have actually been the merge of two previous sets of actions that you had you known very well from FP6 and also FP5, which are the research training networks and the early stage training host fellowships.
And I was extremely glad to come just in time to see your presentation of the success stories earlier on, which is precisely talking about contracts of this kind which are already running.
In in Slovenia, so this shows you already how successful Slovenia has already been seen in understanding the scope of these actions.
So we're continuing with this in one single action.
We want to sort of try to simplify the type of variety of activities that we have, but also to converge into one single type of activity.
The main features are very similar to this activities that we had in FP6.
Of course it's a based on a transnational network of participants.
We contemplate as well the possibility as it was in the past of having mono partners as well.
But of course when you have mono partners or Twinings as such, then we need to have a very good proof that there is international cooperation.
And that is a very large set of international partners that are normally part of this training activities that they will be offering to the researchers.
Also a we are expecting that this training is going to be not just under the umbrella, just a research project is more where we're talking about this research training program.
We want to have a much more structuring effect in what the training of researchers at the early stages in the initial stages of their career is going to be throughout a Europe.
So we're expecting that this training will happen on one part.
Of course, through the research and through a projects which are individualized and personalized to each of the individual researchers.
That will be.
Recruited in this networks but also we are expecting that it will be another serious of training activities which will and this is not something that we're just inventing.
This is something that we are aware that is very necessary for the researchers in order to have a more ample career perspective.
We know that our research is not just about sitting in the laboratory working on research.
There's other needs as well for them to progress in their careers.
They have to have a knowledge of entrepreneurship.
They have to know how to manage their research projects.
Because they might become and most of them will in the future become project managers and have a higher positions in their institutions.
They have to learn logically about IPR issues and they have to know how to communicate their results not just to their fellow scientists but also to the wider public.
On the side of the industry participation, as I said on earlier on, it's very important to have a real serious industry participation in in this activities.
So we are expecting that the business sector will be involved in a direct or indirect way in this networks, either as a full network partner.
So just as one more participant with who will be able to recruit researchers and trained researchers as the level of of the any of the other participants.
Even, and that was something that we would like to see more and more, becoming coordinators of this initial training networks.

Also they can provide research training of this other complementary skills that I was mentioning earlier on that could be smaller companies who are dedicated to maybe communication skills or IPR issues.
And these companies could also be part of this consortium and participate there, and the minimum level that we're expecting is as members of the Supervisory Board.

Of the network there will be obligatory in these networks are supervisory board which is going to be setting the principles of what this training is going to be about, and it's going to vigilate that this is going to be even and consistent throughout the network because we are expecting that one of the greatest benefits of this is going to be not just the quality that is going to be consistent, but there will be a mutual recognition of the training of the quality of the training and the qualifications that will have been obtained in this training period now.

The reason for these three levels that we're expecting here is we we are a bottom up a program, so we are aware that there in certain disciplines, like for example, humanities, which may be industry cannot participate as a full partner and we want to leave enough scope so that everybody gets this culture into their normal training activities.

But of course we are aware as well that in certain areas of research, in the street should be participating at the highest level, and if industries not seem to participate at the highest level in this.
Muscles, then they will be penalized during the evaluation.
And I'm giving an example some project on nanotechnology.
It's where industry normally sucky player should be having one or more partners at participating as a full partner in terms of the what can participate.
What sort of researchers would be eligible in this initial training networks?
These are mostly open for the training of early stage researchers.
I will not go into the definition of.
What we mean by each of these early stage researchers and experienced researchers because they're the same definitions and lives in as in FB6 and earlier on.
It was kindly explained to all of you what these these conditions were.
But just to tell you that we're expecting that more than 80% of the researchers recruited in these networks will be early stage researchers.
But there's also an opening for early postdocs.
We knew that this was a necessary.
We know that in certain areas it's impossible important to give.
Also, more training within this initial training phase two, the first postdoctoral researchers.
We're talking initial training is up to the first five years of post graduate experience.
So within this margin we expect that also first post docs could also be recruited, and then we have an you figure which is the visiting scientists.
This in some ways takes on board this idea of the excellence chairs when we want to do with this is to allow this networks to have the possibility of having.

Researchers were high level and who are a very mostly very senior researchers who are going to be able to transfer knowledge at certain levels are going to be training in certain areas that the network would benefit very much off, but they're not really able or capable to have a inside to be able to have this this this extra training.
So this is again knew addition that we have in here.
Likewise, there's a possibility of organizing conferences which can be.
Open to researchers from outside the network, and in those cases where this A are requested and duly justified, then this will be also given receiving extra funds.
I will not go in more details of what the Community contribution will cover.
It will cover again because I'm a bit sort of using the previous presentations because that's very similar.

We are covering the salaries of the researchers everything which is linked to the researchers costs during their training period in the institution, and then of course we are going to have networking costs, so that will be also everything that we're having now.
I should say most of our our actions are going to be.
Based on flat rate to try and facilitate as much as possible there reporting as well and the management by the executions.

But we will increase from FP6 the networking costs and also there will be the management costs will be up to 7% for those multi partner in networks and this again will help to the for the network to operate.
Now I will pass on to the a lifelong training and career development.

In this case, we are looking at experience researchers, so these are really postdoctoral researchers in most of the cases, or those who have at least four years research experience and the aim of this lifelong training actions are we are talking here about the traditional Marie Curie Fellowships.
Individual fellowships, and these are aiming at complementing or acquiring new skills and competencies.
And also trying to enhance a little bit the possibilities of mobility between sectors many many occasions during the career of a researcher they have.
They need the opportunity to move to another sector is difficult for them to find the funding.
These could provide a the funding for them.
This is going to be implemented in two ways with the traditional Marie Curie Fellowships, with the intra European Fellowships and also the return mechanisms European integration grants and through.
Local funding of of international, regional and national programs.
The AI go one by one.

I will not stop very long because I think most of you probably know about this fellowships, but I would like to stress a here that for this individual, intra European fellowships, it is not excluding first postdocs.
I want to leave this very clear.

We're talking about a career development, but we are aware that in many areas after, when the first postdoc starts already there in the position to start with the career development and become more independent researchers.
So this is an important message that I want to leave here.
It's not that we're not covering them, we're covering the spectrum of what we consider experience researchers now.
Another important thing as well is I don't want to fool anybody here.
The fact that maybe a we're not going to be talking about excellence excellence in terms of the evaluation criteria.
There are many criteria that we're taking into account, but the fact is that we have a large oversubscription in this schemes.
There are many people who want to apply for these schemes, and the reality is that a success rate.

Unfortunately, it's not a very high, so at the end of the day, what you're going to have is that only researchers who can show that they are really the top researchers who are going to the top institutions, and we're showing that they're going to be top a projects will be selected.
So I'm saying this when you are thinking of preparing applications.
In this sense, you have to be very, very clear of the quantity that you're going to be presenting now.
A traditional there, they continue to be up to four 2 two years.

A duration the application is done jointly with the hosting, a research organization and of course we do have a with our our conditions of transnational mobility, because after all, at the basis of everything we are a mobility scheme.
Hi there open for EU Nationals and associated countries and the host institutions have to be in Member States and associated countries.

Now the reintegration grants continue again from FP6 and it's just basically to support those researchers with a one of the Marie Curie Fellowships for more than 18 months to return, possibly to their own institution or to promote the perspectives of their research.
Careers could be somewhere else because of a they have been during mobility.
And this.

Once there, we want to just enhance better, even more their research career perspectives the way that we're expecting this to be done is on a evaluation at regular intervals, and it would be a continuous submission of proposals, and the project can last between 2:00 and 3:00.
Years now I will go to the Co fund.
This is this is a a new type of a program that we're proposing.
In fact, you will have seen that it was.
The deadline is still not there.
We're still working on the on the on the criteria.
Still a lot of discussion going on in terms of how we expect the institutions to be evaluated, but the main aim of Co fund is really to maximize this idea of giving further.
Opportunities for career development in Europe to experience researchers so we want to also use the idea of transnationality and make it more and more common in all the Member States.

The main features is that there will be multi on your proposals and we will take into account knew an existing mobility programs, the possibility of international mobility that we are contemplating a three types outgoing fellowships incoming.
And the possibility of integration and mobility schemes.
What type of organizations are we thinking about in this a Co fund program?
On the one hand, public bodies that means ministries research academies anybody which is already giving this type of a fellowships.
But of course they will have to demonstrate that they are going to have a transnational part to their programs.
In all the cases that will decide, now they always will have to find.
To show this and basically what we will be doing is to fund the transnational part of this programs up to 40%.

Now the other bodies that can apply our public and private bodies, like for example other large research organizations or a possibility as well as having international organizations that run come parable schemes in Europe as part of their of their mission.
As I said earlier on, we're still under discussion in terms of how this evaluation will take a place.
How will be the means to evaluate at mid term how these programs are running and which implications would this have in terms of the progression in their in their funding afterwards?
A the other scheme I want to talk about today and again I think that this could be quite interesting here in Slovenia.
Is the industry, academia, partnerships and pathways.

Now again this we are not just making it up completely knew it's something that we're taking the experience from the past from transfer of knowledge schemes which we had for a development for less favorite regions and for an industry academia exchanges, what we've done is we've taken the things that work best from both and we.
Put it into one single scheme which is going to be directed to the exchanges between industry and academia.

What we want here is to establish and to and to foster longer term corporations between the sectors and it goes back to what I was saying earlier in terms of trying to create a better communication paths between these two sectors and ensure that it's not just going to happen through the training of early stage researchers, but this is also going to happen through the transfer of knowledge, continuous transfer of knowledge and.

Parties between the two sectors, we're expecting that this will be done on the basis of a joint project or transfer of knowledge program, and this is going to be a implemented mostly on the basis of staff secondments, so this is very important because there will be the possibility of recruiting experienced researchers as well into this partnerships.
But the main part here is going to be the Staffs economists, and we're talking stuff 2nd.
Segments and we've made this very, very flexible because we knew from experience that it was not just at the level of experience researchers that this could be beneficial.

We're contemplating early stage researchers, so that means, for example, a pre doc could go for a state in industry as part of their of their acquisition of knowledge and maybe more specific training in certain areas.
Of course, we're contemplating experience researchers, but we also contemplating a research stuff, a technical stuff that could be implicated in this.
A contract in this projects and as well managerial stuff.
This is something that has been many of very often requested from us that we allowed some level of those managerial stuff.
We're actually dealing with this type of projects to be able to exchange knowledge with the managerial stuff, for example from the other sector.
What shall we be covering here?
Salary costs both of their recruited researchers as well from this as well as staff.

Disappointments we will be also covering networking and again we will have this situation of covering costs for organizing, organizing conferences and when these conferences are open to external researchers.

External to this partnership, then we will be funding this as well, which is the minimum to participate and this is I want to stress this here because it's easy, it's easy and what I want to send you the message that they're not so well known, so it gives you a very very good opportunity.
You only need your minimum is 1 research organization and one organization from the private sector 1 in one country Member State and another one in another Member State or associated Country.
So it's minimum and we're talking minimum.
And we're not saying is minimum, but you should be more.
No, this is completely acceptable.
What you need is a good collaboration project between the two sectors and a good exchange program between both of them.
So I would really.
Like you to think about this and consider it as a possibility for a publication.

The project duration will be up to four years and a very important thing is that to try and attract more SMS in participating we will be covering small equipment costs up to 10% of the total contribution, so that again is a very good message to be sending to a possible participants from SMS.
And now for the international dimension.
As I said earlier on all our hosts schemes are open to the participation of third countries.
This is just building on what Carmen kindly explained to all of us very clearly.
So she's made our lives much more easier with all the explanations about the rules for participation.

So basically all our host schemes are open to a participation of 3rd Country National School can be recruited in our host schemes without any limits and also for participation of institutions full participation.
Additionally, in a CBC countries and of course in other third countries that would be according to the rules for participation.
But we have other actions which are falling within this international dimension.
And this I'm just going to go through them relatively quickly because they again are just a continuation of the FB6A actions.
One.
Is there a outgoing international fellowships?
This is to allow researchers European researchers to go outside Europe for a stay of one to two years and then one year return to Europe.
So we guarantee we cover all those salary costs and we guarantee that the person will be covered with for the salaries when they return to the institution in Europe.
Is directed again to experience researchers.
Answer The Community contributions which we will be basically the same as the intra European fellowships.
Then we have the international incoming and these are for researchers coming from third countries to come to the to the EU or to associated countries.
And we can cover an optional one year return for people coming from the developing countries.
Again, it's our experience researchers and community contributions like you know the other individual fellowships.
Then we have the.
International reintegration grants and this is a something to try and deal with.
With these researchers who've left Europe and I've been away for a certain period of time to allow them to make it easier for them and more attractive to return to Europe.
So we're going to give them a contribution of 25,000 euros per year for three to four years.
It's not a lot, but it allows them to establish a project.
It allows them for research costs, and it could even pay researchers or assistance from.
Salaries from this amounts so this is just to make their their entering it back into into a Europe a bit more comfortabl bit easier and we're going to.
And we've changed the room from the past because it used to be five years that you had to be away.
Now with thought of a three years is the maximum that you have to be away because we know that three years is the point of no return.
And that's something that we've learned after all these years of dealing with researchers who.
No way OK, so now I just have this problem.
You cannot see it very clearly because it's a bit small, but I'm sure that this will be publicized.

And of course you can go to our web pages, but just to tell you that a we had a serious of a deadlines, which as Carman said earlier on, were published on the 22nd of December an the budgets are there.
I should say that for the initial training networks is the only scheme that because we know is very oversubscribed, we will have a two step to stage evaluation.
So the first stage for this deadline of these items will be the 7th of March and the second stage will be the 25th of September.
And of course we want to move very quickly with the 1st results coming out in July.
So we're expecting to be giving information quite swiftly.
I wish to say as well that of course all this information and is in the web pages.
I have to stress once and 100 times that our core, a legal instrument, illegal legal document is a work program for each and every of these actions.
But of course we have published a guide for applicants and in all our guide for applicants.
We have a part.
Some of you probably remember in FP six we had this handbooks which were very much appreciated.
We have not done away with them.
Be a be a you know happy about this because they are part of our guide.
For evaluations for applicants.
But basically what we thought was much better to have one single document that was easier for everybody to look into instead of having many documents.

This guide for applicants takes into account all the information which is in the work program which is in the rules for participation and also issues that sometimes maybe are written in the grant agreements.
And maybe you're not so clearly seen in in the work program.
All that is now contained in the specific area where we speak about our schemes to help you prepare your proposals with all the background knowledge and.
I just have the same slide that everybody else only.
I have put the actual page where you can find the calls for the people program and that's all I have to say.
Thank you very much.
